review.title: A System for Probabilistic Linking of Thesauri and Classification Systems
review.abstract: This paper presents a system which creates and visualizes probabilistic semantic links between concepts in a thesaurus and classes in a classification system. For creating the links, we build on the Polylingual Labeled Topic Model (PLL-TM). PLL-TM identifies probable thesaurus descriptors for each class in the classification system by using information from the natural language text of documents, their assigned thesaurus descriptors and their designated classes. The links are then presented to users of the system in an interactive visualization, providing them with an automatically generated overview of the relations between the thesaurus and the classification system.

sections.heading: 2 System Description
sections.text: The system consists of two main components: the first component is responsible for extracting the links with PLL-TM, with each class described in the classification system by a distribution across the thesaurus descriptors; the second component is an interactive browser-based visualization of the links implemented using the JavaScript library D32. Here, the links, i.e. the classes contained in the classification system along with their most likely thesaurus descriptors, are visualized as nodes in an interactive collapsible tree. Probabilistic link extraction is a verified topic model that takes into account multiple languages while limiting the themes of a document to its designations. In the context of this system, PLL-TM models two languages to create links between classes and descriptors.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we presented a system for probabilistic semantic linking of thesaurus descriptors with classes in a classification system. It consists of two components: (1) probabilistic semantic link generation using PLL-TM and (2) interactive visualization of the links. Identification and visualization of latent semantic links between two KOS is helpful in scenarios such as explorative classification browsing and as support during the indexing process. For future work, we plan to apply the system in different domains and evaluate the extracted links with human expert indexers. Furthermore, we plan to develop a (semi-) automatic annotation system that uses the links not only at the global KOS level, but proposes classes and a series of thesaurus descriptors for individual documents.
